questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe pain in her right leg while walking. She used to be able to walk a half-mile (800 m) to the grocery store but has been unable to walk 200 meters without stopping because of the pain over the past month. The pain subsides after 5 minutes, after which she can walk again. She has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 32 years. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, aspirin, and warfarin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an irregularly irregular pulse. The right lower extremity is cooler than the left lower extremity. The skin over the right leg appears shiny and dry. Femoral pulses are palpated bilaterally; pedal pulses are diminished on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography is appropriate in suspected acute limb ischemia (ALI), which may manifest with coolness and decreased pulses in the leg, and is likely in a patient with multiple atherosclerotic risk factors (hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking) and a history of heart disease (i.e., atrial fibrillation). However, the onset of ALI is typically acute, involving severe, acute pain, paresthesia, and weakness of the leg. This patient likely has PAD, in which duplex ultrasonography can be helpful to assess blood flow status; however, a different, quicker, and less expensive test should be performed first to confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although CT angiography (CTA) is useful to identify atherosclerotic plaques, it is not the first step in diagnosing PAD because it is expensive, invasive, and exposes patients to contrast agents and radiation.

C) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is used for diagnosing PAD and also allows for simultaneous treatment of arterial stenosis through percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA). However, this procedure is invasive and expensive, and revascularization is not the first-line therapy for PAD with claudication symptoms only on exertion. This patient's diagnosis must first be confirmed with a noninvasive test.

D) CORRECT:

Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is the first-line diagnostic test in PAD because it is readily available, noninvasive, as well as highly specific and sensitive. Reduced ABI values between 0.4–0.9 indicate mild to moderate PAD with claudication, whereas values below 0.4 correlate to severe PAD with resting pain and/or gangrene. An ABI > 1.4 in patients with suspected PAD may indicate calcific sclerosis with noncompressible vascular walls (e.g., in patients with diabetes). A low ABI (≤ 0.9) and a high ABI (> 1.4) are associated with an increased risk of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality. In patients with a normal ABI and high suspicion for PAD, exercise testing may be required. Vascular imaging (e.g., with MR angiography) is not required for diagnosis but helps assess site(s) and extent of arterial occlusion or stenosis and collateral blood flow if revascularization is planned.

E) INCORRECT:

MR angiography (MRA) can identify atherosclerotic plaques (which lead to PAD). In contrast to other imaging techniques, MRA does not require administering a contrast agent and does not expose the patient to radiation. However, MRA is not the initial step in diagnosing PAD because it is expensive and not readily available.
questions.hint: The presence of claudication pain, trophic skin changes, and diminished pulses in a chronic smoker should raise concern for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) Fontaine stage IIb (claudication at a walking distance < 200 m).

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing difficulty achieving an erection for 6 months. During this period, he has had to reduce his hours as a construction worker because of pain in his lower back and thighs and a progressive lower limb weakness when walking for longer distances. His pain resolves after resting for a few minutes, but it recurs when he returns to work. He also reports that his pain is improved by standing still. His last visit to a physician was 25 years ago. He is sexually active with 4 female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His father has coronary artery disease and his mother died of a ruptured intracranial aneurysm at the age of 53 years. He has recently taken sildenafil, given to him by a friend, with no improvement in his symptoms. His only other medication is ibuprofen as needed for back pain. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years.  He is 172.5 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 169/98 mm Hg. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. His hemoglobin A1c is 6.2%. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?

choices.text: Papular rash over the palms and soles

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased pulses are a common finding in peripheral arterial disease, for which this patient is at high risk. Decreased bilateral femoral pulses indicate occlusion of either the bilateral iliac arteries or the aortic bifurcation. Lesions at either of these locations cause aortoiliac occlusive disease (Leriche syndrome), which manifests with the classic triad of buttock, hip, or thigh claudication; erectile dysfunction; and absent or diminished femoral pulses. Given this patient's high risk for cardiovascular disease and complaints in accordance with two-thirds of the classic triad, Leriche syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

Atrophy of the affected limbs is also common in Leriche syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is usually caused by multiple sclerosis or stroke. Although this patient has multiple risk factors for cerebrovascular disease (smoking, obesity, possibly hypertension), stroke generally manifests with acute unilateral sensory and/or motor symptoms, while this patient has chronic, bilateral symptoms. Multiple sclerosis generally has symptoms disseminated in space (different locations in the central nervous system) and time (relapsing/remitting). Additionally, pseudoclaudication and erectile dysfunction are atypical symptoms of multiple sclerosis. Given this patient's risk factors and symptoms, another diagnosis is far more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

A papular rash of the palms and soles can be seen in secondary syphilis. Although this patient is at risk for syphilis (unprotected sex, multiple partners), which can have a broad range of presenting symptoms, syphilis is unlikely to present solely with erectile dysfunction and exertional thigh cramping.
Image Description:

Partially confluent and partially scaling red papules and macules of ∼2–5 mm diameter are visible on the palms and wrists.

This appearance is typical of secondary syphilis.

D) INCORRECT:

Jugular venous distention is a sign of some cardiac conditions (e.g., heart failure). Although this patient has risk factors for cardiac disease (smoking, obesity), his erectile dysfunction and intermittent claudication suggest a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased anal tone can be a sign of spinal cord compression (due to lumbosacral neurological lesions or spinal stenosis) or autonomic neuropathy, which can additionally manifest with erectile dysfunction and leg pain, both of which are seen in this patient. However, in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis who have neurogenic pain or pseudoclaudication, pain is generally exacerbated with standing, unlike what is seen here, and relieved with sitting. Type 2 diabetes mellitus can cause vascular claudication due to accelerated atherosclerosis as well as erectile dysfunction and decreased anal sphincter tone due to autonomic neuropathy. Although this patient has risk factors for diabetes mellitus (e.g., obesity), his HbA1c is < 6.5%.

F) INCORRECT:

A painless foot ulcer is usually a complication of diabetes mellitus. Although diabetes can cause erectile dysfunction (autonomic neuropathy), it is unlikely to cause exertional leg pain. Additionally, this patient's hemoglobin A1c was 6.2% (≥ 6.5% is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus). A painful foot ulcer is more consistent with this patient's condition.
questions.hint: This patient has multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., obesity, smoking, and positive family history). He has erectile dysfunction and symptoms of intermittent claudication (thigh pain and weakness on exertion, temporarily relieved by rest) that suggest a chronic condition characterized by progressive arterial occlusion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician with a 6-month history of bilateral calf pain. The pain occurs every time he tries walking his dog a few blocks and is more severe on the right side. He has coronary artery disease, essential hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 43 years and drinks two alcoholic beverages a day. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and aspirin. He is 183 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 113 kg (250 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 129/72 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a gallop without murmurs. The skin over his lower extremities is shiny and there is reduced hair growth below the knee. Femoral and popliteal pulses are palpable bilaterally. Dorsal pedal pulses are 1+ on the left and absent on the right. Ankle-brachial index is 0.5 in the right leg, and 0.6 in the left leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Conservative interventions, such as structured exercise therapy, are the best initial steps in the management of PAD if claudication is present and there is no evidence of chronic limb-threatening ischemia or acute limb ischemia. Initial management would also include modifying risk factors through smoking cessation, antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, and managing hypertension and diabetes mellitus if present.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol can be used to treat hypertension or arrhythmias. This patient's intermittent claudication suggests PAD, which can be managed by controlling cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and atherosclerosis. Because this patient has well-controlled blood pressure with no symptoms or signs of arrhythmia, additional medication is unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Vascular bypass surgery can be used to restore adequate limb perfusion in patients with PAD. This intervention is only considered once conservative and pharmacological treatment have failed to provide symptomatic relief, or if there is evidence of chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) on physical examination. Because this patient has not received any initial therapy and has no evidence of CLTI on physical examination, a more conservative approach is needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Cilostazol is used to provide symptomatic relief for intermittent claudication in patients with PAD. It is an adjunct to first-line therapy, and not indicated as a primary modality of treatment. Pharmacological treatment for PAD is typically indicated once more conservative treatment options have failed.

E) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) with stenting can be used to revascularize peripheral vessels. PTA with stenting is only considered once conservative and pharmacological treatment have failed to provide symptomatic relief, or if there is evidence of chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) on physical examination. Because this patient has not received any initial therapy and does not have evidence of CLTI on physical examination, a more conservative approach must first be considered.
questions.hint: This patient's history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and smoking, intermittent calf pain on exertion (claudication pain), and ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.4–0.9 are consistent with moderate peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The trophic skin changes below the knee (shiny skin and decreased hair growth) suggest femoropopliteal disease.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of pain, cramps, and tingling in his lower extremities over the past 6 months. The patient reports that the symptoms worsen with walking more than two blocks and are completely relieved by rest. Over the past 3 months, his symptoms have not improved despite his participating in supervised exercise therapy. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years but quit 3 months ago. He does not drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Examination shows loss of hair and decreased skin temperature in the lower legs. Femoral pulses are palpable; pedal pulses are diminished. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase III inhibitor that has vasodilatory, antiplatelet, and antithrombotic properties. This drug may be considered as a therapeutic trial for 3–6 months in patients with PAD and claudication who remain symptomatic despite conservative measures (e.g., smoking cessation, supervised exercise therapy). Cilostazol improves symptoms of claudication and walking distance but has not been shown to decrease major cardiovascular events. Adverse effects are common and include headache, palpitations, diarrhea, and dizziness.

In addition to cilostazol, all patients with PAD should receive medical therapy with an antiplatelet agent (aspirin or clopidogrel), a statin to reduce the risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, and mortality, and antidiabetic agents if appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Compression stockings are a treatment option for patients with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI). In contrast to PAD, the pain in CVI is characteristically worse with standing for long periods of time and may improve (not worsen) with walking, since calf muscles aid in venous return. Because compression stockings exert external pressure on the limbs, this treatment would further impede blood flow in this patient with PAD, thereby worsening his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Endarterectomy is a treatment option for patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) or PAD who remain symptomatic despite conservative and pharmacologic measures. This patient does not present with any symptoms that would suggest CLTI (e.g., rest pain, ulcers, gangrene). Although he has persistent symptoms of PAD despite lifestyle changes (smoking cessation and supervised exercise therapy), another, less invasive treatment should be tried first at this stage.

D) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) is a treatment option for patients with PAD and chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) or lifestyle-limiting claudication persisting despite conservative and pharmacologic treatment. This patient does not present with any symptoms that would suggest CLTI (e.g., rest pain, ulcers, gangrene). Although he has persistent PAD symptoms despite lifestyle changes (smoking cessation and supervised exercise therapy), another, less invasive treatment option is recommended at this stage.

E) INCORRECT:

Bypass surgery is a treatment option for patients with PAD and chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) or lifestyle-limiting claudication persisting despite conservative and pharmacologic treatment. This patient does not present with any symptoms that would suggest CLTI (e.g., rest pain, ulcers, gangrene). Although he has persistent PAD symptoms despite lifestyle changes (smoking cessation and supervised exercise therapy), another, less invasive treatment option is recommended at this stage.
questions.hint: This patient presents with intermittent claudication of the calves that worsens upon exertion and is completely relieved by rest. These features are suggestive of femoropopliteal disease, the most common subtype of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of increasing calf cramping in both legs when walking for the past year. Symptoms are especially severe when walking on an incline. He has been exercising on a treadmill 4 times a week; he walks until the pain starts and then continues after a short break. He has a history of hypertension controlled with enalapril. He smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years but quit 5 months ago. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The calves and feet are pale. Femoral pulses can be palpated bilaterally; pedal pulses are absent. His ankle-brachial index is 0.6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intensive treatment and optimization of risk factors for atherosclerotic disease improve outcomes in PAD and prevent ischemic events. Statins help to control hyperlipidemia and should be offered to all patients with PAD. Antiplatelet therapy (e.g., with clopidogrel) is indicated in all symptomatic patients. Other cardiovascular risk factors that require long-term treatment are hypertension (controlled with enalapril in this patient) and hyperglycemia.

A thorough workup of this patient is warranted, as PAD often coexists with coronary artery disease, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and renal disease.

B) INCORRECT:

During operative vascular reconstruction (e.g., bypass surgery, endarterectomy), an autologous vein (e.g., great saphenous vein) is used to bypass the stenosis and restore blood flow in the ischemic limb. This treatment option is indicated in advanced disease if conservative and pharmacological treatment has failed or if chronic limb-threatening ischemia (e.g., resting pain, ulcer, gangrene) is present.

C) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is indicated in advanced PAD if conservative and pharmacological treatment has failed or if chronic limb-threatening ischemia (e.g., resting pain, ulcer, gangrene) is present.

D) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin and piperacillin is the treatment of choice for severe soft tissue infection (e.g., cellulitis). This patient does not have erythematous skin lesions, purulent exudate, or systemic signs of infection such as fevers, chills, or confusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Rest and orthotic braces are the treatment of choice for insertional tendinopathy. While tendinopathy is characterized by pain, especially on movement, this condition would not manifest with pallor, pulselessness, and decreased ankle-brachial index.
questions.hint: This patient presents with increasing calf cramping on exertion, a history of smoking and hypertension, pale lower extremities, and absent pedal pulses, the combination of which suggests peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 3-month history of progressively worsening right calf pain. She reports that the pain occurs after walking for about 10 minutes and resolves when she rests. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes lisinopril and simvastatin daily. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. Her pulse is 78/min and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. Femoral and popliteal pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Left pedal pulses are 1+; right pedal pulses are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.65 in the right leg and 0.9 in the left leg. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?

choices.text: Abdominal aortic aneurysm requiring open surgical repair

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lower extremity PAD is associated with an increased risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), as both diseases have a similar pathogenesis involving systemic atherosclerosis and shared risk factors (e.g., smoking, hypertension, etc). However, she is at even higher risk for development of a different complication.

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphedema refers to abnormal accumulation of fluid in the interstitium from lymphatic system dysfunction (e.g, due to injury, infection, congenital abnormality, following surgery or radiation, etc.). Although this condition may initially manifest similarly, this patient's exertional pain and lack of edema effectively rule out this diagnosis. Additionally, the presence of PAD is not associated with an increased risk of lymphedema.

C) INCORRECT:

Limb amputation is used as a last resort in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) if other treatment options (e.g., endovascular or surgical revascularization) have proven unsuccessful or if patients have limited life expectancy, deep space infections, or wet gangrene. Although the risk of CLTI requiring amputation is significantly higher in patients with diabetes, only a minority of patients with PAD will require limb amputation and this patient is at greater risk for a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a manifestation of venous thromboembolism, and should always be considered as a differential diagnosis in patients with asymmetric lower extremity pain. Common risk factors for DVT include immobility, malignancy, obesity, and increased age. While atherosclerosis (including PAD) and DVT share some risk factors (e.g., smoking), there is no clear association between PAD and risk of DVT.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of PAD suggests systemic atherosclerosis and is associated with an increased risk of acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI). However, the majority of cases of AMI arise from intracardiac emboli (i.e., mural thrombi, valvular disorders, arrhythmias), rather than thrombosis from atherosclerotic disease. The risk of another complication is higher.

F) CORRECT:

PAD is a very strong predictor of coexisting coronary artery disease, as both diseases have a similar pathogenesis (atherosclerosis) and shared risk factors (e.g., smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes). Compared to healthy individuals, patients with PAD are at significantly increased risk for myocardial infarction and stroke. Evaluation and management of underlying coronary artery disease is recommended for patients with PAD, and risk factors should be addressed.

First-line therapy of lower extremity PAD is management of cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., smoking, diabetes, hypertension) and exercise (walking) therapy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with intermittent claudication (pain on exertion that is relieved on rest) of her right calf with diminished pedal pulses and decreased ABI (normal range: 1–1.3). These features are characteristic of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Her risk factors include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of tingling pain in the sole of his right foot when he raises it above chest level during exercises. He reports that he started exercising regularly 2 months ago and that his right calf cramps when he uses the incline feature on the treadmill, forcing him to take frequent breaks. The pain completely disappears after resting for a few minutes. He has an 8-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His only medication is metformin. His pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. Straight leg raise test elicits pallor and tingling pain in the right foot. There is no pain in the back. His muscle strength is normal. Femoral pulses are palpable; right pedal pulses are absent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Vasculitis of the right popliteal artery
Acute thrombosis of right popliteal vein

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms of arterial insufficiency (paresthesia, intermittent claudication) in his right calf and foot and palpable femoral pulses but absent right pedal pulses indicate stenosis of the femoropopliteal artery, the most common site of peripheral arterial disease. The foot tingling on leg elevation is due to the decrease in arterial blood flow to the limb when raised above the level of the heart (usually insignificant, but can cause symptoms in patients with preexisting arterial insufficiency). The cramping pain upon exertion (e.g., walking on the treadmill) and relief at rest are characteristic of intermittent claudication (stage II according to Fontaine classification), which is a symptom of arterial insufficiency. Chronic smoking, hypertension, advanced age, and male gender are all significant risk factors for the development of PAD.
Image Description:

The Buerger test is used to evaluate peripheral arterial disease of the lower limbs.

With the patient in the supine position, elevate the lower limbs to ∼45° at the hip and evaluate for foot pallor. If no pallor occurs, ask the patient to plantarflex and dorsiflex or to rotate their feet a few times, looking for exercise-induced pallor.

Next, ask the patient to sit up with their legs hanging off the examination table and evaluate the time taken for the color to return to the feet and for the veins to fill again.

Foot pallor on elevation, or reactive hyperemia or delayed venous refilling on dependency, indicate arterial insufficiency (positive Buerger sign). A venous filling time of > 20 seconds may indicate advanced ischemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Paresthesia of the extremities is a characteristic feature of diabetic neuropathy, a complication seen in patients with chronic diabetics, as seen here. However, diabetic neuropathy typically affects the extremities symmetrically (glove and stocking distribution) and neurological examination would show sensory loss in the affected areas.

C) INCORRECT:

Vasculitis and thrombosis of small and medium-sized arteries, e.g., the popliteal artery, are the underlying pathogenesis of thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), for which chronic smoking is the most important risk factor. TAO manifests with features of arterial insufficiency (paresthesia, claudication, absent peripheral pulses in the affected limb), as seen in this patient. However, TAO typically affects more than one limb, commonly manifests with features of Raynaud phenomenon and migratory thrombophlebitis, and rarely affects patients > 45 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the right popliteal vein can manifest with sudden, severe pain in the calf that exacerbates on exertion but would not disappear on rest. In addition, paresthesia that worsens on raising the limb above the level of the heart and absent pedal pulses on examination are not features of venous disease. Instead, acute DVT would show edema, warmth, calf tenderness, and, possibly, distended superficial veins in the affected limb, none of which are present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis caused by progressive narrowing of the central spinal canal (e.g., due to spondylolisthesis, intervertebral disk herniation) can manifest with pseudoclaudication (neuropathic claudication). Although tingling and cramping are symptoms of pseudoclaudication, and the condition occurs unilaterally in about 30% of cases, it typically involves the entire leg and would not cause absent pedal pulses. Additionally, a straight-leg raising test would elicit pain in the back and/or lower limbs.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

F) INCORRECT:

Although aortoiliac occlusive disease can manifest with unilateral paresthesia and claudication of the calf and foot, examination would show absent femoral pulses. Additionally, patients with significant aortoiliac stenosis would typically have claudication symptoms in the thigh and gluteal regions.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of the most common subtype of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of right lower extremity pain and burning while walking. The pain subsides with rest. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Her current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Examination shows a lack of hair and decreased skin temperature over the right foot. The right pedal pulse is not palpable. The physician adds a drug to her regimen that causes vasodilation and inhibits the aggregation of platelets and the proliferation of smooth muscle cells. Which of the following drugs was most likely added?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dabigatran is an anticoagulant that directly inhibits thrombin, thereby disrupting the coagulation cascade. Unlike the drug used in this patient, dabigatran does not affect platelet aggregation, prevent smooth muscle proliferation, or cause vasodilation. Moreover, it is not indicated to treat PAD. Dabigatran can be used to manage venous thromboembolism, atrial fibrillation, or other conditions requiring long-term anticoagulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Eptifibatide exerts its antiplatelet activity through glycoprotein receptor IIb/IIIa inhibition. While it does inhibit platelet aggregation, eptifibatide does not cause vasodilation or inhibit smooth muscle proliferation. This drug is used to treat unstable angina and to prevent adverse cardiac events during percutaneous coronary intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Bosentan blocks vascular endothelin receptors, causing vasodilation. It is primarily used to reduce pulmonary vascular resistance in patients with pulmonary hypertension. Unlike the drug administered here, bosentan does not prevent platelet aggregation and is not used to treat PAD.

D) INCORRECT:

Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that acts through ADP receptor blockade (ADP receptor inhibitor). While clopidogrel reduces platelet aggregation, it does not cause vasodilation or inhibit smooth muscle proliferation. Furthermore, this patient is already on an antiplatelet agent (aspirin), and there is no indication for dual antiplatelet therapy (e.g., endovascular placement of a peripheral arterial stent or previous bypass with synthetic graft).

E) CORRECT:

Cilostazol is indicated in patients with PAD to help improve the symptoms of intermittent claudication. The drug acts by inhibiting phosphodiesterase 3, causing an increased intracellular concentration of cAMP that results in vascular smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation as well as reduced platelet aggregation. Cilostazol also inhibits proliferation of smooth muscle cells via an unknown mechanism. Common side effects include headache, diarrhea, palpitations, and tachycardia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with right lower extremity claudication, trophic skin changes (decreased temperature and lack of hair), and absent pedal pulse. These features suggest peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of crampy left lower extremity pain that is exacerbated by walking and relieved by rest. The pain is especially severe when he walks on an incline. He has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry and hairless skin over the left foot. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Osteophytic compression of the lumbar spinal canal
Thrombosing vasculitis of the popliteal artery
Intimal plaque in the posterior tibial artery
Fibrin clot in the left popliteal vein
Microvascular compromise of the superficial peroneal nerve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteophytic compression of the lumbar spinal canal may lead to neurogenic claudication, causing lower leg pain on exertion. However, neurogenic claudication is relieved by flexion at the waist, so classically it is less severe when walking uphill. Moreover, this condition does not cause trophic skin changes such as hairlessness of the foot.

B) INCORRECT:

Thrombosing vasculitis of the popliteal artery could be seen in thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO). TAO is one of the possible causes of lower extremity claudication, and smoking is strongly associated with this condition. However, the symptoms of TAO are commonly bilateral, whereas this patient's symptoms are unilateral. Moreover, the condition classically manifests with superficial thrombophlebitis, Raynaud phenomenon, and early ischemic ulceration, none of which are present in this case. Finally, TAO typically manifests in patients < 45 years of age, making the diagnosis less likely in this 65-year-old man.

C) CORRECT:

An intimal plaque in the posterior tibial artery is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation, which is consistent with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). PAD is strongly associated with diabetes, hypertension, and smoking, all of which are present in this case. The disease begins with the buildup of lipids and fibrous material beneath the tunica intima in peripheral arteries. With time, focal accumulation of these substances can cause stenosis and reduced blood flow to downstream tissues, manifesting as episodic ischemia (in this case, claudication). Typical physical exam findings include decreased or absent peripheral pulses, atrophic skin changes (i.e., dry, shiny, or hairless skin), or chronically non-healing foot wounds. The diagnosis is confirmed via ankle-brachial index.
Image Description:

MR angiography lower limbs

Numerous stenoses (examples indicated by arrows) are present. Portions of several bilateral pelvic, femoral, and lower limb arteries are not visible.

D) INCORRECT:

A fibrin clot in the left popliteal vein would manifest as a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Although smoking and diabetes are risk factors for the development of DVT, this condition manifests with acute onset unilateral leg pain, swelling, and erythema. There is most often a history of surgery or inactivity as well that causes venous stasis, neither of which are present in this case. Furthermore, DVT does not cause claudication, pedal alopecia, or the foot to turn pale on elevation.

E) INCORRECT:

Microvascular compromise of the superficial peroneal nerve (or any other sensory nerve of the distal lower extremity) occurs with long-standing diabetes. Through a complex series of pathways, chronic hyperglycemia induces microvascular damage in the vessels of the perineurium, causing axonal damage that manifests as diabetic neuropathy. This patient is at significant risk to develop neuropathy as a complication of his diabetes. However, he presents with intermittent unilateral lower extremity pain and evidence of skin changes, neither of which are consistent with diabetic neuropathy. Moreover, he does not report pain, burning, tingling, or numbness in the dorsal foot and toes (the dermatome of the superficial peroneal nerve), all of which are characteristic symptoms of diabetic neuropathy.

F) INCORRECT:

Systemic hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a form of small vessel disease that typically arises in the setting of severe hypertension (≥ 180/120 mmHg). The intimal response to sustained blood pressures in this range results in a characteristic “onion skin” appearance on histological examination of vascular tissue. This process classically causes ischemic damage in the kidneys, but it is not implicated in cases of vascular insufficiency in the extremities. Moreover, this patient's blood pressure is only 140/92 mm Hg, which is much lower than what is necessary to cause hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.
questions.hint: Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a common test used to diagnose this condition.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful nonhealing lesion that developed on his left toes 2 weeks ago after he accidentally hit them at work. He also has a 4-month history of pain in his calves when walking, which initially subsided after rest but now persists regardless of activity. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic retinopathy. His medications include insulin, ramipril, and metoprolol. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 2–3 beers daily. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 89/min, blood pressure is 146/90 mm Hg, and BMI is 29 kg/m2. Physical examination shows well-demarcated areas of necrosis on the left distal third and fourth toes with surrounding erythema. Popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are not palpable on the left side and are decreased on the right. His hemoglobin A1c is 8.2%, leukocyte count is 7500/mm3, and serum creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL. MR angiography shows a normal left femoral artery. There is extensive occlusion of the proximal left popliteal artery and segmental stenosis of the left tibial arteries and the fibular artery. The distal left anterior tibial artery above the ankle is patent, and there are multiple collaterals. Antibiotic treatment is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Above-knee amputation might be indicated in patients with CLTI but is generally considered a last resort in extensive, severe gangrene or when revascularization therapy fails. Another treatment option is more appropriate at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Cilostazol is indicated in patients with PAD and intermittent claudication, as its vasodilator effects alleviate the symptoms of claudication. However, in patients with CLTI, cilostazol is not effective and another treatment option is indicated at this point.

C) INCORRECT:

Smoking cessation should be recommended in all patients with PAD as smoking is the greatest risk factor for this condition, contributing to further progression of the disease. However, smoking cessation will not reverse this patient's severe PAD. Although strict smoking cessation is indicated in this patient, he presents with CLTI, which requires urgent treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Revascularization is indicated in CLTI and can be performed via percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) with or without stenting. PTA is usually the preferred treatment option because of its lower risk, morbidity, mortality, and shorter hospital stay compared to other treatments. However, in patients with long-segment or multifocal stenoses or occlusions, like this one, long-term patency rates of PTA are inferior compared to another treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Structured exercise therapy is indicated in patients with PAD and intermittent claudication, as it significantly improves claudication symptoms, increasing the pain-free walking distance. This patient, however, presents with CLTI, which requires a limb-salvage intervention at this point.

F) CORRECT:

In patients with CLTI, urgent revascularization therapy is indicated to prevent limb-threatening arterial occlusion. Revascularization can be performed via percutaneous transluminal angioplasty or bypass surgery, depending on the extension and location of the stenotic/occluded segment. In patients with extensive disease manifesting with long-segment and/or multifocal stenoses or occlusions, as seen here, femorotibial bypass surgery is preferred over endovascular revascularization, as long-term patency rates are higher.

This patient also has dry gangrene. After successful revascularization, amputation of unsalvageable regions may be performed (staged procedure).
Image Description:

There are two types of peripheral artery bypass: anatomical bypass (which follow the normal anatomical vascular pathways) and extraanatomical bypass (which circumvent them).

When naming these bypasses, the proximally located donor vessel is listed first, followed by the distally located recipient vessel.
questions.hint: Pain at rest and painful, nonhealing ulcers in a patient with a history of intermittent claudication and stenosis and occlusion on MR angiography are consistent with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and indicate chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of increasing malaise, headache, fever, and pain in his left foot. He reports that his left big toe has looked “weird” for several weeks but was not painful until now. He has not seen a physician in the past 15 years. Family history is remarkable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years and drinks two 12-oz beers daily. He takes no medications. He appears distressed. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 112 kg (246 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 94/50 mm Hg. Examination of the left foot shows erythema and edema up to the level of the midfoot. The left first toe appears moist and enlarged, with grayish-black discoloration and blistering. The right foot shows dry, shiny, bluish skin with brittle nails. Dorsalis pedis pulses are not palpable and posterior tibial pulses are weak bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick is decreased in both feet up to the level of the ankle. Leukocyte count is 17,000/mm3. In addition to intravenous fluids and antibiotics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Amputation of the left first toe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is a revascularization procedure that can be used in the treatment of PAD. This patient's wet gangrene of the left first toe, however, requires immediate management before proceeding to treatment of any underlying condition.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with suspected PAD most likely developed wet gangrene of the left first toe that was further complicated by sepsis. In wet gangrene, emergency amputation and debridement of infected and necrotic tissue are indicated. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered promptly after obtaining blood cultures and later adjusted based on the results. In addition, this patient requires a workup and treatment for PAD and any other conditions (e.g., diabetes mellitus) that may have contributed to the development of wet gangrene.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin A1c levels can be measured to screen for diabetes mellitus (DM), which this patient might have given his risk factors for type 2 DM (increased BMI, a family history of diabetes, older age). Type 2 DM can manifest with distal symmetric polyneuropathy, which, in combination with the immunosuppressive state associated with type 2 DM, can contribute to nonhealing foot ulcers and consequent infection. Although this patient requires future screening for DM, he first requires urgent management for the wet gangrene of the first left toe.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI can be used in the evaluation of patients with suspected osteomyelitis, which this patient most likely has in the left first toe as a result of wet gangrene. However, the wet gangrene requires urgent management, which does not include an MRI of the foot.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the ankle-brachial index is the first step in the workup for PAD. Before proceeding to a workup for PAD, however, this patient requires urgent management for the wet gangrene of the first left toe.
questions.hint: In a patient with findings consistent with peripheral artery disease (PAD), such as absent pulses, decreased sensation, and trophic changes, a moist and edematous left first toe with grayish-black discoloration and blistering raises concern for wet gangrene.

questions.text:
An 83-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia reports one year of cramping pain in her right thigh and calf that consistently occurs when she walks on flat ground for 90 meters or more. The pain promptly resolves when she stops walking and stands still. She notes mild bilateral lower-leg swelling that is maximal at the end of the day and resolves overnight. She also notes mild tingling in both feet. She has no dyspnea or back pain.
On examination, the patient has no jugular venous distention. Her lungs are clear, and no murmurs or gallops are present. She has symmetric mild pitting edema of both ankles and feet. No pulses are palpable in either foot. Neurologic examination reveals decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in both feet, and there is normal strength in all muscle groups of both lower extremities. Deep-tendon reflexes are absent at both ankles and are normal at both knees. A straight-leg raising maneuver is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses best explains this patient’s leg pain?

choices.text: Neurogenic claudication secondary to lumbar spinal stenosis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mild dependent edema in the absence of a systemic cause suggests chronic venous insufficiency. Venous insufficiency is not painful unless it is severe or complicated by ulceration or infection.

B) INCORRECT:

The pain of neurogenic claudication (usually caused by lumbar spinal stenosis) often persists for a short time after the patient stops walking. Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis may note absence of pain when seated and improvement of symptoms when bending forward. Their physical examination may reveal asymmetric motor, sensory, and deep-tendon reflex findings in the legs.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with exertional lower-extremity pain, it is important to differentiate arterial claudication from neurogenic claudication. Arterial claudication typically causes reproducible exertional lower-extremity pain that resolves promptly with the cessation of exercise. The ipsilateral dorsalis pedis and posterial tibial pulses are not usually palpable in patients with arterial claudication. However, many older patients with cardiovascular risk factors have nonpalpable pulses in both feet, regardless of whether they have exertional pain.

Key learning point: Lower-extremity pain that reproducibly worsens with exertion and promptly improves with rest is suggestive of claudication secondary to peripheral arterial disease.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has a symmetric distal sensory polyneuropathy that is characteristic of diabetes mellitus. Although this type of diabetic neuropathy can be painful, it is typically bilateral, and it is not exertional.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbosacral radiculopathy due to a herniated disk usually causes back pain and leg pain at rest. Physical examination may reveal ipsilateral neurologic findings corresponding to the level of the herniated disk.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes reports a one-year history of left calf pain upon walking 100 yards. He currently takes lisinopril, amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, and liraglutide.
On examination, he is found to have an absent left dorsalis pedis and diminished left posterior tibial pulses. A complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are normal. The patient’s resting ankle-brachial index is 0.99 on the right and 0.85 on the left.
Which one of the following medications would be most appropriate for this patient to initiate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with PAD should be treated with a single antiplatelet agent (usually aspirin) to prevent future cardiovascular events. The addition of a second antiplatelet agent, such as ticagrelor or clopidogrel, in patients with PAD does not clearly improve outcomes and is associated with increased risk for bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Pentoxifylline is sometimes used in patients with symptomatic PAD who cannot take cilostazol; however, its effectiveness has not been clearly established. Cilostazol was shown to be superior to pentoxifylline in the only comparative study of the two drugs.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with PAD should be treated with a single antiplatelet agent (usually aspirin) to prevent future cardiovascular events. The addition of a second antiplatelet agent, such as ticagrelor or clopidogrel, in patients with PAD does not clearly improve outcomes and is associated with increased risk for bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase inhibitor with antiplatelet properties, is indicated for patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and has been shown to improve walking distance after 3 to 6 months of therapy, compared with placebo. This medication is contraindicated in patients with heart failure and should be used with caution in patients with renal dysfunction. Headache and diarrhea are relatively common adverse effects.

Of note, the choice of cilostazol for this patient is based on current guidelines, but new data may change these recommendations. The COMPASS trial showed that, in patients with stable atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (27% of whom had PAD), the addition of rivaroxaban to aspirin was associated with fewer major adverse cardiovascular events than aspirin alone. Rivaroxaban may therefore be another reasonable medication to prescribe to patients with PAD, especially if they are otherwise at low bleeding risk.

Key learning point: Symptoms of intermittent claudication that persist despite aspirin therapy and cardiovascular risk-factor modification can improve if treated with cilostazol.

E) INCORRECT:

Long-acting nitrates, such as isosorbide, are used for patients with exertional angina and do not appear to benefit those with intermittent claudication.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man reports a 6-month history of right calf pain that occurs after 30 meters of walking and resolves promptly with rest. His medical history includes insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and a previous stroke.
On examination, he has diminished pedal pulses on the right, with palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. The left pedal, femoral, and popliteal pulses are normal. No bruits are present. Neurologic examination of the lower extremities is normal except for symmetrically diminished ankle reflexes, light touch sensation, and pinprick sensation in the feet.
The resting ankle-brachial index is 1.10 on the left and 0.95 on the right (reference range, 1.01–1.40).
Which one of the following next tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with runoff

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Invasive angiography is appropriate after noninvasive testing has suggested the presence of PAD and revascularization is being considered.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography would be useful for localization of lesions in planning for intervention. Given that the resting ABI is borderline, the next best test would be for confirmation of ischemia with exercise.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasound imaging is useful for patients with an abnormal ABI to better localize and characterize the extent of disease or to follow patients who have previously had peripheral arterial revascularization.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the lumbar spine might be considered in a patient with typical features of pseudoclaudication attributable to spinal stenosis. Such patients may have asymmetric neurologic findings in the lower extremities, and pain in the back or leg provoked by ambulation and by certain changes in position. This patient's symmetric neurologic findings in the feet likely reflect diabetic neuropathy.

E) CORRECT:

The initial test in a patient with suspected peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is the ankle-brachial index (ABI), which is interpreted as follows:

• Normal: 1.01–1.40
• Borderline: 0.91–1.00
• Abnormal: ≤0.90

Although the ABI is reasonably sensitive, a normal value is insufficient to exclude the diagnosis of PAD when symptoms strongly suggest arterial claudication. Exercise improves the sensitivity of ABI in detecting PAD; thus, ABI after exercise is the most appropriate next test in a patient with intermittent claudication and a normal or borderline resting ABI.

Toe-brachial index is used for patients with an ABI >1.40 due to noncompressible vessels.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next test in a patient with symptoms of claudication and a borderline-low resting ankle-brachial index is an exercise ankle-brachial index.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman with hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and mild asthma reports a one-year history of pain in her calves when she walks more than a few blocks. She was recently started on cilostazol, and she reports that her walking distance until onset of pain has improved somewhat.
She takes aspirin 81 mg daily, hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, cilostazol 100 mg twice daily, and pravastatin 20 mg daily. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years but does not drink alcohol. Both of her parents had hypertension but not coronary artery disease.
Her current blood pressure is 129/75 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 62 beats per minute. Her pedal pulses are not palpable. Femoral pulses are normal.
Laboratory testing identifies a creatinine concentration of 0.9 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1) and the following lipid levels: LDL cholesterol, 137 mg/dL; HDL cholesterol, 39 mg/dL; and total cholesterol, 215 mg/dL.
Results of liver function tests are normal. The ankle-brachial pressure index is 0.7 in both lower extremities.
In addition to encouraging walking and smoking cessation, what is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Replace the aspirin 81 mg daily with clopidogrel 75 mg daily
Replace the pravastatin 20 mg daily with atorvastatin 80 mg daily
Start warfarin, with a target international normalized ratio of 2.0
Continue aspirin 81 mg daily, and add clopidogrel 75 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is an appropriate antiplatelet agent for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pentoxifylline is of questionable clinical benefit for managing symptomatic claudication in patients with peripheral vascular disease. This patient is already taking cilostazol, which has been shown in clinical trials to improve walking distance in patients with claudication.

C) CORRECT:

Peripheral vascular disease is characterized by claudication (pain with walking), diminished peripheral pulses, and skin changes in the affected extremities (e.g., skin cool to the touch, bluish discoloration of the feet). An ankle-brachial pressure index ≤0.9 supports a diagnosis of peripheral vascular disease.

One goal of care in patients with peripheral vascular diseases is to reduce symptoms. In the case of intermittent claudication, this can be achieved with exercise therapy and pharmacologic therapies such as cilostazol. Of note, none of the answer options in this case would provide symptomatic benefit. A second goal is to reduce the patient’s cardiovascular risk. Guidelines indicate that patients with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) — including peripheral vascular disease — receive high-intensity statin therapy. High-intensity statin therapy with atorvastatin 40 mg to 80 mg reduces overall ASCVD risk more than low-intensity statin therapy with pravastatin 20 mg.

Key learning point: The dose of atorvastatin that is recommended for a patient with symptomatic peripheral vascular disease is 40 to 80 mg daily.

D) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is not indicated unless a thrombus is present or a thromboembolic event has occurred.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is an appropriate antiplatelet agent for this patient; there is no proven advantage in adding clopidogrel or substituting it for aspirin (unless the patient has a contraindication to aspirin, in which case clopidogrel may be chosen as an alternative antiplatelet agent).

questions.text: A 74-year-old man reports a 6-month history of right calf pain that occurs after 30 meters of walking and resolves promptly with rest. His medical history includes insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and a previous stroke. On examination, he has diminished pedal pulses on the right, with palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. The left pedal, femoral, and popliteal pulses are normal. Neurologic examination of the lower extremities is normal except for symmetrically diminished ankle reflexes, light touch sensation, and pinprick sensation in the feet. The resting ankle-brachial index is 1.10 on the left and 0.95 on the right (reference range, 1.01–1.40). Which one of the following next tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with runoff

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Invasive angiography is appropriate after noninvasive testing has suggested the presence of PAD and revascularization is being considered.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography would be useful for localization of lesions in planning for intervention. Given that the resting ABI is borderline, the next best test would be for confirmation of ischemia with exercise.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasound imaging is useful for patients with an abnormal ABI to better localize and characterize the extent of disease or to follow patients who have previously had peripheral arterial revascularization.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the lumbar spine might be considered in a patient with typical features of pseudoclaudication attributable to spinal stenosis. Such patients may have asymmetric neurologic findings in the lower extremities, and pain in the back or leg provoked by ambulation and by certain changes in position. This patient's symmetric neurologic findings in the feet likely reflect diabetic neuropathy.

E) CORRECT:

The initial test in a patient with suspected peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is the ankle-brachial index (ABI), which is interpreted as follows:

• Normal: 1.01–1.40
• Borderline: 0.91–1.00
• Abnormal: ≤0.90

Although the ABI is reasonably sensitive, a normal value is insufficient to exclude the diagnosis of PAD when symptoms strongly suggest arterial claudication. Exercise improves the sensitivity of ABI in detecting PAD; thus, ABI after exercise is the most appropriate next test in a patient with intermittent claudication and a normal or borderline resting ABI.

Toe-brachial index is used for patients with an ABI >1.40 due to noncompressible vessels.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next test in a patient with symptoms of claudication and a borderline-low resting ankle-brachial index is an exercise ankle-brachial index.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of a 10-month history of crampy left lower extremity pain that is exacerbated by walking and relieved by rest. The pain is especially severe when he walks on an incline. He has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry and hairless skin over the left foot. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Osteophytic compression of the lumbar spinal canal
Intimal plaque in the posterior tibial artery
Fibrin clot in the left popliteal vein
Microvascular compromise of the superficial peroneal nerve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteophytic compression of the lumbar spinal canal may lead to neurogenic claudication, causing lower leg pain on exertion. However, neurogenic claudication is relieved by flexion at the waist, so classically it is less severe when walking uphill. Moreover, this condition does not cause trophic skin changes such as hairlessness of the foot.

B) CORRECT:

An intimal plaque in the posterior tibial artery is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation, which is consistent with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). PAD is strongly associated with diabetes, hypertension, and smoking, all of which are present in this case. The disease begins with the buildup of lipids and fibrous material beneath the tunica intima in peripheral arteries. With time, focal accumulation of these substances can cause stenosis and reduced blood flow to downstream tissues, manifesting as episodic ischemia (in this case, claudication). Typical physical exam findings include decreased or absent peripheral pulses, atrophic skin changes (i.e., dry, shiny, or hairless skin), or chronically non-healing foot wounds. The diagnosis is confirmed via ankle-brachial index.
Image Description:

MR angiography lower limbs

Numerous stenoses (examples indicated by arrows) are present. Portions of several bilateral pelvic, femoral, and lower limb arteries are not visible.

C) INCORRECT:

A fibrin clot in the left popliteal vein would manifest as a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Although smoking and diabetes are risk factors for the development of DVT, this condition manifests with acute onset unilateral leg pain, swelling, and erythema. There is most often a history of surgery or inactivity as well that causes venous stasis, neither of which are present in this case. Furthermore, DVT does not cause claudication or pedal alopecia.

D) INCORRECT:

Microvascular compromise of the superficial peroneal nerve (or any other sensory nerve of the distal lower extremity) occurs with long-standing diabetes. Through a complex series of pathways, chronic hyperglycemia induces microvascular damage in the vessels of the perineurium, causing axonal damage that manifests as diabetic neuropathy. This patient is at significant risk to develop neuropathy as a complication of his diabetes. However, he presents with intermittent unilateral lower extremity pain and evidence of skin changes, neither of which are consistent with diabetic neuropathy. Moreover, he does not report pain, burning, tingling, or numbness in the dorsal foot and toes (the dermatome of the superficial peroneal nerve), all of which are characteristic symptoms of diabetic neuropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a form of small vessel disease that typically arises in the setting of severe hypertension (≥ 180/120 mmHg). The intimal response to sustained blood pressures in this range results in a characteristic “onion skin” appearance on histological examination of vascular tissue. This process classically causes ischemic damage in the kidneys, but it is not implicated in cases of vascular insufficiency in the extremities. Moreover, this patient's blood pressure is only 140/92 mm Hg, which is much lower than what is necessary to cause hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.
questions.hint: Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a common test used to diagnose this condition.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of increasing calf cramping in both legs when walking for the past year. Symptoms are especially severe when walking on an incline. He has been exercising on a treadmill 4 times a week; he walks until the pain starts and continues after a short break. He has a history of hypertension controlled with enalapril. He smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years but quit 5 months ago. The physical examination reveals pale calves and feet. Femoral pulses can be palpated bilaterally; pedal pulses are absent. His ankle-brachial index is 0.6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intensive treatment and optimization of risk factors for atherosclerotic disease improve outcomes in PAD and prevent ischemic events. Statins help to control hyperlipidemia and should be offered to all patients with PAD. Antiplatelet therapy (e.g., with clopidogrel) is indicated in all symptomatic patients. Other cardiovascular risk factors that require long-term treatment are hypertension (controlled with enalapril in this patient) and hyperglycemia.

A thorough workup of this patient is warranted, as PAD often coexists with coronary artery disease, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and renal disease.

B) INCORRECT:

During operative vascular reconstruction (e.g., bypass surgery, endarterectomy), an autologous vein (e.g., great saphenous vein) is used to bypass the stenosis and restore blood flow in the ischemic limb. This treatment option is indicated in advanced disease if conservative and pharmacological treatment has failed or if critical limb ischemia (e.g., resting pain, ulcer, gangrene) is present.

C) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is indicated in advanced PAD if conservative and pharmacological treatment has failed or if critical limb ischemia (e.g., resting pain, ulcer, gangrene) is present.

D) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin and piperacillin is the treatment of choice for severe soft tissue infection (e.g., cellulitis). This patient does not have erythematous skin lesions, purulent exudate, or systemic signs of infection such as fevers, chills, or confusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Rest and orthotic braces are the treatment of choice for insertional tendinopathy. While tendinopathy is characterized by pain, especially on movement, this condition would not manifest with pallor, pulselessness, and decreased ankle-brachial index.
questions.hint: This patient presents with increasing calf cramping on exertion, a history of smoking and hypertension, pale lower extremities, and absent pedal pulses, the combination of which suggests peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the office with a 3-month history of progressively worsening right calf pain. She reports that the pain occurs after walking for about 10 minutes and resolves when she rests. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes lisinopril and simvastatin daily. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. Femoral and popliteal pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Left pedal pulses are 1+; right pedal pulses are absent. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.65 in the right leg and 0.9 in the left leg. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?

choices.text: Abdominal aortic aneurysm requiring open surgical repair

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lower extremity PAD is associated with an increased risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), as both diseases have a similar pathogenesis involving systemic atherosclerosis and shared risk factors (e.g., smoking, hypertension, etc). However, she is at even higher risk for development of a different complication.

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphedema refers to abnormal accumulation of fluid in the interstitium from lymphatic system dysfunction (e.g, due to injury, infection, congenital abnormality, following surgery or radiation, etc.). Although this condition may initially manifest similarly, this patient's exertional pain and lack of edema effectively rule out this diagnosis. Additionally, the presence of PAD is not associated with an increased risk of lymphedema.

C) INCORRECT:

Limb amputation is used as a last resort in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) if other treatment options (e.g., endovascular or surgical revascularization) have proven unsuccessful or if patients have limited life expectancy, deep space infections, or wet gangrene. Although the risk of CLTI requiring amputation is significantly higher in patients with diabetes, only a minority of patients with PAD will require limb amputation and this patient is at greater risk for a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a manifestation of venous thromboembolism, and should always be considered as a differential diagnosis in patients with asymmetric lower extremity pain. Common risk factors for DVT include immobility, malignancy, obesity, and increased age. While atherosclerosis (including PAD) and DVT share some risk factors (e.g., smoking), there is no clear association between PAD and risk of DVT.

E) CORRECT:

PAD is a very strong predictor of coexisting coronary artery disease, as both diseases have a similar pathogenesis (atherosclerosis) and shared risk factors (e.g., smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes). Compared to healthy individuals, patients with PAD are at significantly increased risk for myocardial infarction and stroke. Evaluation and management of underlying coronary artery disease is recommended for patients with PAD, and risk factors should be addressed.

First-line therapy of lower extremity PAD is management of cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., smoking, diabetes, hypertension) and exercise (walking) therapy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with intermittent claudication (pain on exertion that is relieved on rest) of her right calf with diminished pedal pulses and decreased ABI (normal range: 1–1.3). These features are characteristic of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Her risk factors include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with exertional calf pain that begins after walking three blocks and resolves with brief rest. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. There are decreased hair follicles over the distal lower limbs, and dorsalis pedis pulses are diminished. He denies lower back pain or numbness (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Ankle-brachial index
0.80
0.9 - 1.3


Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis can cause exertional leg pain but typically presents with neurogenic claudication, relieved by forward flexion of the spine, and often includes lower back pain or radicular symptoms. The absence of these neurologic symptoms, combined with vascular findings such as diminished distal pulses and a reduced ankle-brachial index, differentiates this condition from lumbar spinal stenosis.

B) CORRECT:

Peripheral artery disease manifests with intermittent claudication, characterized by exertional calf pain relieved by rest. This condition is often due to atherosclerosis, especially in individuals with significant smoking history and advanced age. Physical findings such as decreased hair over the distal lower limbs and diminished dorsalis pedis pulses indicate reduced arterial blood flow. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.80, below the normal range of 0.9 to 1.3, confirms peripheral arterial obstruction. These clinical and diagnostic findings collectively support the diagnosis of peripheral artery disease.

Key learning point: Intermittent claudication, loss of hair over the shins, and an ABI of 0.80 are indicative of peripheral artery disease, specifically chronic limb ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy typically manifests as symmetric distal sensory loss with burning or tingling, not exertional pain relieved by rest. The patient's symptoms, along with diminished dorsalis pedis pulses and decreased hair over the lower extremities, suggest an ischemic process. The low ankle-brachial index further supports a vascular etiology, not diabetic neuropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic venous insufficiency often presents with edema and skin changes like hyperpigmentation, with pain worsening on standing and improving with leg elevation. The exertional pain pattern, diminished distal pulses, and decreased hair follicles, along with a low ankle-brachial index, suggest arterial rather than venous pathology, making chronic venous insufficiency unlikely.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with calf discomfort while walking that disappears during short rest periods. The pain typically recurs after walking about two blocks, limiting his daily routines. He has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes and chronic hypertension. Physical examination reveals diminished pedal pulses and mild hair loss over the dorsum of the foot. The ankles appear pink and warm at rest. No signs of joint deformities, edema, or erythema are noted.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis can cause leg pain with ambulation, but it is often associated with back discomfort or radicular symptoms, relieved by positional changes. The patient's diminished pedal pulses and foot hair loss indicate vascular insufficiency, not a neurologic cause. Cardiovascular risk factors further support a vascular etiology over neurogenic claudication.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetic peripheral neuropathy typically presents as chronic, symmetrical sensory loss with burning, tingling, or numbness, often present at rest. The patient's exertional calf discomfort relieved by rest suggests an ischemic process, not neuropathy. Diminished pedal pulses and foot hair loss indicate vascular insufficiency, distinguishing this from neuropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic venous insufficiency usually presents with leg discomfort worsened by prolonged standing, accompanied by edema, varicose veins, or skin changes. The patient's exercise-induced pain, diminished pedal pulses, and foot hair loss suggest arterial compromise, not venous disease. Intact warm, pink ankles support normal perfusion at rest, inconsistent with venous insufficiency.

D) CORRECT:

Peripheral arterial disease manifests with intermittent claudication, characterized by exertional calf discomfort that resolves with rest. This condition results from atherosclerotic narrowing of peripheral arteries, reducing blood flow during increased muscular demand. Diminished pedal pulses and hair loss over the dorsum of the foot indicate chronic reduced perfusion. The patient's history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension contributes to endothelial dysfunction, accelerating atherosclerosis in lower extremity vessels. These clinical features and risk factors align with the pathophysiology of peripheral arterial disease, where progressive arterial narrowing leads to insufficient blood delivery during activity.

Key learning point: Intermittent claudication, characterized by leg pain during walking that is relieved by rest, is a classic symptom of peripheral arterial disease, often seen in patients with diabetes and hypertension.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old man presents with left calf pain after walking two blocks, which resolves with rest. He has a 45-year history of heavy cigarette smoking. He notices dry skin and decreased hair growth on the left foot. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are diminished on the left side (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Ankle-brachial index (left)
0.65
0.9 - 1.3


Ankle-brachial index (right)
1.0
0.9 - 1.3



Which of the following interventions is most likely to improve his walking distance?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pentoxifylline, a hemorheologic agent, was considered for intermittent claudication due to its effects on blood viscosity and red blood cell deformability. However, it shows minimal improvement in walking distance. The primary issue in this patient is large-vessel occlusion, not microcirculatory abnormalities, making pentoxifylline less effective.

B) INCORRECT:

Endovascular stenting is reserved for patients with symptoms unresponsive to conservative measures or critical limb ischemia. In intermittent claudication, characterized by exercise-induced pain resolving with rest, initial management favors noninvasive approaches like supervised exercise programs. Stenting is not justified as the initial intervention due to its invasiveness and potential complications.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with intermittent claudication due to peripheral arterial disease, a supervised exercise program is the first-line intervention to improve walking distance. This approach enhances collateral circulation, endothelial function, and muscular efficiency, increasing ischemic pain-free walking capacity. Regular, structured exercise, typically involving walking with rest intervals, promotes metabolic adaptations and reduces inflammation. The ankle-brachial index provides objective evidence of hemodynamic compromise, supporting conservative, lifestyle-based interventions before invasive treatments.

Key learning point: A supervised exercise program is the most effective non-pharmacological intervention to improve claudication distance in patients with peripheral artery disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Bypass surgery is reserved for critical limb ischemia or symptoms unresponsive to conservative measures. This patient has moderate peripheral arterial disease without limb-threatening ischemia. Surgical revascularization is invasive and carries risks, making it inappropriate before trying less invasive therapies like supervised exercise.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of cramping calf pain after walking one block that improves with rest. He has a 15-year smoking history and notices mild numbness in both feet. On examination, bilateral pedal pulses are diminished, and the skin over his legs appears thin. There are no ulcers or significant edema.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography offers detailed arterial visualization but involves risks such as contrast-induced nephropathy and radiation exposure. It is generally reserved for planning interventions after noninvasive tests like the ankle-brachial index confirm peripheral arterial disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Conventional angiography is invasive and used for detailed vascular anatomy assessment when planning revascularization. It carries risks like contrast-induced nephropathy and vascular injury. Noninvasive tests like the ankle-brachial index are preferred initially for peripheral arterial disease evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasound provides detailed information on arterial stenoses but is typically used after an initial screening test like the ankle-brachial index (ABI) confirms peripheral arterial disease. It is more resource-intensive and is reserved for cases where revascularization is considered or further anatomical detail is needed.

D) CORRECT:

The ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a noninvasive test that compares the systolic blood pressure at the ankle with that at the arm to assess for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). An ABI value below 0.90 indicates arterial compromise. This patient presents with claudication, diminished pedal pulses, and a history of smoking, all suggestive of PAD. The ABI provides objective evidence of arterial insufficiency and serves as a baseline for monitoring disease progression or treatment efficacy. Its simplicity and cost-effectiveness make it the preferred initial diagnostic step for PAD.

Key learning point: In patients with suspected peripheral artery disease, non-invasive vascular lab exams such as the Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and Doppler ultrasound are the first-line investigations to assess the presence and severity of the disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 10-month history of crampy pain in his left lower extremity that worsens with walking and is relieved by rest. The pain is particularly severe when walking on an incline. He has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and takes metformin. He has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. On examination, the skin over his left foot is dry and hairless. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Intimal plaque in the posterior tibial artery.
