Microvascular compromise of the superficial peroneal nerve.
Osteophytic compression of the lumbar spinal canal.
Fibrin clot in the left popliteal vein.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An intimal plaque in the posterior tibial artery is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation, which is consistent with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). PAD is strongly associated with diabetes, hypertension, and smoking, all of which are present in this case. The disease begins with the buildup of lipids and fibrous material beneath the tunica intima in peripheral arteries. With time, focal accumulation of these substances can cause stenosis and reduced blood flow to downstream tissues, manifesting as episodic ischemia (in this case, claudication). Typical physical exam findings include decreased or absent peripheral pulses, atrophic skin changes (i.e., dry, shiny, or hairless skin), or chronically non-healing foot wounds. The diagnosis is confirmed via ankle-brachial index.

Key learning point: Peripheral arterial disease causes exertional leg pain (claudication) due to atherosclerotic intimal plaques in peripheral arteries, especially in patients with diabetes, hypertension, and a history of smoking.
Image Description:

MR angiography lower limbs

Numerous stenoses (examples indicated by arrows) are present. Portions of several bilateral pelvic, femoral, and lower limb arteries are not visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Microvascular compromise of the superficial peroneal nerve (or any other sensory nerve of the distal lower extremity) occurs with long-standing diabetes. Through a complex series of pathways, chronic hyperglycemia induces microvascular damage in the vessels of the perineurium, causing axonal damage that manifests as diabetic neuropathy. This patient is at significant risk to develop neuropathy as a complication of his diabetes. However, he presents with intermittent unilateral lower extremity pain and evidence of skin changes, neither of which are consistent with diabetic neuropathy. Moreover, he does not report pain, burning, tingling, or numbness in the dorsal foot and toes (the dermatome of the superficial peroneal nerve), all of which are characteristic symptoms of diabetic neuropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a form of small vessel disease that typically arises in the setting of severe hypertension (≥ 180/120 mmHg). The intimal response to sustained blood pressures in this range results in a characteristic “onion skin” appearance on histological examination of vascular tissue. This process classically causes ischemic damage in the kidneys, but it is not implicated in cases of vascular insufficiency in the extremities. Moreover, this patient's blood pressure is only 140/92 mm Hg, which is much lower than what is necessary to cause hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteophytic compression of the lumbar spinal canal may lead to neurogenic claudication, causing lower leg pain on exertion. However, neurogenic claudication is relieved by flexion at the waist, so classically it is less severe when walking uphill. Moreover, this condition does not cause trophic skin changes such as hairlessness of the foot.

E) INCORRECT:

A fibrin clot in the left popliteal vein would manifest as a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Although smoking and diabetes are risk factors for the development of DVT, this condition manifests with acute onset unilateral leg pain, swelling, and erythema. There is most often a history of surgery or inactivity as well that causes venous stasis, neither of which are present in this case. Furthermore, DVT does not cause claudication or pedal alopecia.
questions.hint: Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a common test used to diagnose this condition.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of worsening calf cramping in both legs when walking over the past year. The symptoms are particularly severe when walking on an incline. He exercises on a treadmill four times a week, walking until the pain starts and then resuming after a short break. He has a history of hypertension managed with enalapril. He previously smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years and quit 5 months ago. On examination, his calves and feet are pale. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally, but pedal pulses are absent. His ankle-brachial index is 0.6. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is indicated in advanced PAD if conservative and pharmacological treatment has failed or if critical limb ischemia (e.g., resting pain, ulcer, gangrene) is present.

B) INCORRECT:

Eccentric exercise is the treatment of choice for insertional tendinopathy (e.g., chronic Achilles tendinopathy). While tendinopathy is characterized by pain, especially on movement, this condition would not manifest with pallor, pulselessness, and decreased ankle-brachial index.

C) CORRECT:

Intensive treatment and optimization of risk factors for atherosclerotic disease improve outcomes in PAD and prevent ischemic events. Statins help to control hyperlipidemia and should be offered to all patients with PAD. Antiplatelet therapy (e.g., with clopidogrel) is indicated in all symptomatic patients. Other cardiovascular risk factors that require long-term treatment are hypertension (controlled with enalapril in this patient) and hyperglycemia.

A thorough workup of this patient is warranted, as PAD often coexists with coronary artery disease, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and renal disease.

Key learning point: Peripheral arterial disease should be managed with antiplatelet therapy and statins to reduce cardiovascular risk and prevent disease progression.

D) INCORRECT:

During operative vascular reconstruction (e.g., bypass surgery, endarterectomy), an autologous vein (e.g., great saphenous vein) is used to bypass the stenosis and restore blood flow in the ischemic limb. This treatment option is indicated in advanced disease if conservative and pharmacological treatment has failed or if critical limb ischemia (e.g., resting pain, ulcer, gangrene) is present.

E) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin and piperacillin is the treatment of choice for severe soft tissue infection (e.g., cellulitis). This patient does not have erythematous skin lesions, purulent exudate, or systemic signs of infection such as fevers, chills, or confusion.
questions.hint: This patient presents with increasing calf cramping on exertion, a history of smoking and hypertension, pale lower extremities, and absent pedal pulses, the combination of which suggests peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with diabetes presents with bilateral leg discomfort that occurs with walking and resolves with rest. Physical examination shows diminished pedal pulses and dry, atrophic skin. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?

choices.text: CT angiography of the lower extremities

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toe-brachial index is indicated when the resting ankle-brachial index is greater than 1.4 (suggesting noncompressible vessels due to medial calcific sclerosis) or in patients with suspected chronic limb-threatening ischemia. It is not the initial diagnostic test for typical intermittent claudication.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is indicated if revascularization is planned or there is diagnostic uncertainty after initial noninvasive testing. It involves contrast exposure and radiation, making it inappropriate as a first-line screening tool for suspected peripheral arterial disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography can identify elevated peak systolic velocities suggesting peripheral arterial disease (PAD), but it is typically used if revascularization is being considered or the diagnosis is uncertain. It is not the appropriate first-line diagnostic test for suspected PAD.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Resting ankle-brachial index (ABI) is the first-line diagnostic test for suspected nonacute peripheral arterial disease (PAD). It is noninvasive and has high sensitivity and specificity for PAD, with an ABI ≤ 0.9 confirming the diagnosis. The clinical presentation of exertional leg discomfort relieved by rest with diminished pulses suggests intermittent claudication from PAD.

E) INCORRECT:

Transcutaneous oximetry is used to measure tissue perfusion in patients with suspected chronic limb-threatening ischemia or for assessment of nonhealing wounds. This patient's presentation suggests intermittent claudication rather than severe ischemia requiring tissue perfusion measurement.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents with a nonhealing wound and severe leg pain that worsens at night. Examination shows a 2-cm punched-out ulcer on the lateral malleolus with well-defined borders, purulent discharge, and surrounding erythema. Pedal pulses are not palpable. Vital signs are BP, 105/60; P, 93; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). The ankle-brachial index is 0.6. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics and obtain urgent surgical consultation
Discharge with outpatient wound care follow-up
Obtain CT angiography before further treatment decisions
Start cilostazol and refer for structured exercise therapy
Apply dry gauze dressing and elevate the extremity

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- An infected arterial ulcer (fever, erythema, purulent discharge) in a patient with significant peripheral arterial disease (ankle-brachial index of 0.6, absent pulses) necessitates the immediate initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical consultation. Infected arterial ulcers can rapidly progress to life-threatening complications and require aggressive immediate management.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate given the clinical signs of infection (e.g., fever, erythema, and purulent discharge) in a patient with arterial insufficiency. Infected arterial ulcers can progress to sepsis and require immediate intervention rather than outpatient management.

C) INCORRECT:

While imaging may eventually be needed for revascularization planning, the immediate priority is addressing the acute infection with antibiotics and surgical evaluation. Delaying treatment for imaging studies is inappropriate if there are signs of infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Cilostazol and exercise therapy are appropriate for intermittent claudication in stable peripheral arterial disease, but this patient has an infected ulcer requiring immediate intervention. These treatments do not address the acute infectious complication.

E) INCORRECT:

Dry gauze dressing and elevation are inappropriate for an infected arterial ulcer. Infection requires immediate antibiotic therapy and surgical evaluation, and elevation may worsen arterial insufficiency by reducing the already compromised blood flow.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents with a 4-day history of severe toe pain that worsens at night and improves when sitting upright. Physical examination reveals a well-demarcated gray-black lesion on the great toe without signs of infection, absent pedal pulses, and cool lower extremities bilaterally. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies like CT angiography are useful for surgical planning but should not delay urgent surgical evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are typically reserved for wet gangrene or when there are signs of superinfection.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has dry gangrene evidenced by the gray-black discoloration without signs of superinfection. Urgent vascular surgery consultation is indicated to evaluate for possible revascularization, as limb salvage may be achievable with prompt intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

In dry gangrene without signs of infection, debridement is not the initial intervention and should be deferred until after vascular assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

Pain management alone is insufficient for this presentation of peripheral arterial disease with tissue necrosis. The patient requires urgent evaluation for possible revascularization to prevent limb loss.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of cramping pain in his right calf. The pain reliably occurs after walking two city blocks and is consistently relieved within five minutes of stopping to rest. He denies any pain at rest, numbness, or tingling. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. On examination, his lower extremities are cool to the touch with thin, shiny skin and sparse hair growth bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The hallmark symptom is intermittent claudication, an exertional cramping pain in a muscle group that is reproducibly caused by exercise and relieved by rest. This occurs due to atherosclerotic narrowing of arteries, leading to a supply-demand mismatch of blood flow during activity. His significant risk factors (age, smoking, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia) strongly support this diagnosis. Physical exam findings of chronic limb ischemia, including cool skin, trophic changes (shiny skin, hair loss), further confirm reduced arterial circulation. The initial diagnostic test is the ankle-brachial index (ABI).

B) INCORRECT:

While this patient has diabetes, the pain from peripheral neuropathy is typically a constant burning, tingling, or numbness in a “stocking-glove” distribution that is often worse at rest or at night. The patient denies numbness or tingling, and his pain is exertional cramping. While he may have coexisting neuropathy, it does not explain his primary presenting symptom of claudication.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis can cause leg pain with activity. However, the pain is localized to the affected joint, in this case the knee, not the calf. The pain is also typically described as an ache that is worst with initial activity after a period of rest. This patient's calf pain and the presence of trophic skin changes on exam are inconsistent with osteoarthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) may present with unilateral calf pain. However, DVT is an acute condition, not a chronic 6-month complaint. The pain is typically constant, not specifically related to exertion, and is usually accompanied by unilateral edema, erythema, and warmth. This patient's chronic, exertional symptoms and lack of swelling are inconsistent with DVT.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis can cause neurogenic claudication, which is leg pain with walking. However, the pain is typically described as burning or numbness and is relieved by changes in posture, such as leaning forward or sitting, rather than simply by rest. This patient's cramping pain, which is relieved promptly with rest alone, and his trophic skin changes are not features of spinal stenosis.
questions.hint: The reproducible, exertional nature of the pain, its prompt relief with rest, and the patient’s strong risk factors are characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of cramping pain in both calves. The pain reliably occurs after walking two blocks and is relieved within minutes of rest. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. His medications include lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. On examination, his dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are 1+ bilaterally. The skin on his lower legs is cool and shiny with scant hair. Ankle-brachial index is 0.72 on the right and 0.75 on the left. In addition to counseling on risk factor modification, which medication should be initiated to specifically improve his claudication symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet medication used for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events in patients with peripheral arterial disease, and it can be used as an alternative to aspirin. While it is an important part of managing this patient's overall cardiovascular risk, its mechanism is aimed at preventing thrombosis, not at directly alleviating the exertional limb ischemia that causes claudication symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor, is a first-line pharmacologic treatment for improving claudication symptoms. It works by causing vasodilation and inhibiting platelet aggregation, which increases blood flow to the limbs and has been shown to improve maximal walking distance. Its use is recommended in patients who have failed to respond to a structured exercise program and risk factor modification alone. A critical high-yield fact is that cilostazol is contraindicated in patients with heart failure of any severity due to concerns about increased mortality with this drug class in that population.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent recommended for all patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease to reduce the risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, and cardiovascular death. However, its primary role is secondary prevention of atherothrombotic events, and it has not been shown to significantly improve the specific symptom of claudication or increase walking distance.

D) INCORRECT:

Pentoxifylline is a hemorheologic agent that was historically used for claudication. It is thought to work by decreasing blood viscosity and improving red blood cell flexibility. However, its clinical efficacy is considered marginal at best, and current clinical practice guidelines give it a weak recommendation, noting it is not very effective for treating claudication symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. It is used for conditions such as atrial fibrillation or venous thromboembolism. Anticoagulation is not indicated for the routine management of stable atherosclerotic peripheral arterial disease.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical features are typical of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) with intermittent claudication.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe, burning pain in his right foot. The pain has been worsening over the past month, is most severe at night, and is partially relieved by dangling his foot off the bed. His history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. On examination, he has a small, non-healing ulcer on the tip of his right great toe, and his right foot is cool and pale with dependent rubor. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are not palpable. Ankle-brachial index is 0.35 on the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admission for intravenous antibiotics and local wound care
Scheduling an outpatient lower extremity arterial duplex ultrasound
Prescription for a long-acting opioid and close follow-up
Initiation of cilostazol and a supervised exercise program

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While this patient has a non-healing ulcer that may require wound care and could become infected, these interventions do not address the underlying cause, which is severe arterial insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Lower extremity arterial duplex ultrasound is a useful non-invasive study for evaluating peripheral artery disease. However, scheduling this on an outpatient basis is inappropriate given the urgency of chronic limb-threatening ischemia.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic limb-threatening ischemia represents the most advanced stage of peripheral artery disease and carries a high risk of amputation without prompt intervention. The primary goal is limb salvage, which requires urgent revascularization to restore adequate blood flow to the distal limb. Therefore, immediate consultation with a vascular surgeon is necessary to plan for procedures such as angioplasty, stenting, or surgical bypass.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the patient is experiencing severe pain that requires management, prescribing opioids and arranging follow-up fails to address the limb-threatening ischemia. This approach would be purely palliative, mask the worsening of the condition, and significantly delay the necessary management step, greatly increasing the likelihood of major amputation.

E) INCORRECT:

Cilostazol and a supervised exercise program are first-line therapies for intermittent claudication, a less severe form of peripheral artery disease. These interventions are aimed at improving walking distance and functional status. However, they are not indicated and will not be effective for chronic limb-threatening ischemia.
questions.hint: The presence of ischemic rest pain, a non-healing ulcer, and a severely reduced ankle-brachial index indicates a chronic limb-threatening ischemia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a six-month history of cramping pain in his left calf that occurs after walking two blocks and is relieved by rest. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. On examination, his left dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are diminished. The skin on his left foot is cool and shiny with sparse hair growth. An ankle-brachial index is 0.65 on the left and 0.95 on the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in this patient's management?

choices.text: Referral for peripheral angiography and stenting
Addition of cilostazol to his regimen
Initiation of a supervised exercise program
Ordering a CT angiogram of the lower extremities

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Revascularization procedures such as angiography and stenting are considered for patients with severe, lifestyle-limiting claudication that is refractory to conservative management or for those with critical limb ischemia (e.g., rest pain, non-healing ulcers). Because this patient has not yet attempted first-line conservative therapy, this invasive procedure is not the appropriate initial step.

B) INCORRECT:

Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor that can improve symptoms of intermittent claudication. However, it is considered a second-line therapy. It is typically added for patients who do not respond adequately to first-line management.

C) CORRECT:

The most appropriate initial intervention for symptomatic peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication is a supervised exercise program. This is the first-line, evidence-based therapy for improving walking distance and quality of life in patients with claudication. The program typically involves walking on a treadmill to the point of near-maximal claudication pain, followed by rest, repeated for 30–60 minutes, three times per week. This therapy is thought to work by improving muscle metabolism, endothelial function, and promoting the development of collateral circulation. Comprehensive management also includes aggressive risk factor modification, such as smoking cessation, and continued optimal medical therapy for diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.

D) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of peripheral artery disease has already been established by the history, physical examination, and confirmatory ankle-brachial index. Anatomic imaging with CT angiography is not necessary for initial management and is reserved for preprocedural planning when revascularization (e.g., stenting or bypass surgery) is being considered.
questions.hint: This patient's history, physical examination, and ankle-brachial index are classic for peripheral artery disease causing intermittent claudication.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the clinic due to a 6-month history of cramping pain in his right calf. The pain reliably occurs after walking two blocks and is relieved within minutes of stopping. He denies pain at rest. His medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and a 40-pack-year smoking history. On physical examination, his femoral pulses are 2+ bilaterally. The right popliteal, dorsalis pedis, and posterior tibial pulses are nonpalpable. The left-sided distal pulses are 1+. The right foot is cool to the touch with scant hair growth. An ankle-brachial index is 0.6 on the right. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortoiliac occlusive disease would cause claudication in the buttocks, hips, and thighs, not isolated to the calf. A key differentiating finding is that significant stenosis at this level would result in diminished or absent femoral pulses, which are described as normal (2+) in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for peripheral artery disease (PAD) causing intermittent claudication. The location of the stenosis can be determined by the symptoms and pulse examination. Calf claudication is most commonly caused by stenosis in the superficial femoral or popliteal arteries. The physical examination confirms this localization: the femoral pulses are normal, indicating adequate inflow from the aorta and iliac arteries, while the pulses distal to the femoral artery are absent on the affected side. The low ankle-brachial index of 0.6 confirms moderate PAD, and the cool skin with hair loss are signs of chronic ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis causes neurogenic claudication, which can be confused with vascular claudication. However, the pain is typically relieved by leaning forward or sitting, not just by stopping. Furthermore, spinal stenosis would not cause absent distal pulses, skin changes of ischemia, or an abnormal ankle-brachial index.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient has diabetes and may have neuropathy, the pain pattern is not typical. Neuropathic pain is often described as burning or tingling, is frequently present at rest, and is not reliably reproduced by a specific amount of exertion. The classic findings on vascular examination are inconsistent with neuropathy as the cause of his exertional pain.

E) INCORRECT:

A popliteal artery aneurysm typically manifests as an asymptomatic pulsatile mass behind the knee or with symptoms of acute limb ischemia due to thrombosis or distal embolization. It is not a common cause of chronic, stable intermittent claudication, which is caused by fixed atherosclerotic stenosis.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents with persistent left foot discomfort. He has poorly controlled type 2 diabetes. He describes a cool sensation in his toes and notices a reddish coloration that becomes more pronounced when the foot is in a dependent position. Physical examination reveals markedly reduced pedal pulses, and the skin is cool to the touch. He also mentions that small cuts on his foot take an unusually long time to heal.
Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infectious cellulitis typically presents with warmth, tenderness, and systemic symptoms like fever. The cool skin and reduced pedal pulses in this patient suggest a vascular issue. The dependent redness and delayed wound healing align more with arterial insufficiency than infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic venous insufficiency can cause dependent redness due to venous stasis. However, it typically presents with warm skin, edema, and intact pulses. The cool skin and reduced pedal pulses in this patient suggest arterial insufficiency rather than venous congestion.

C) CORRECT:

Arterial insufficiency in elderly patients with diabetes results from atherosclerotic changes that reduce blood flow to the extremities. This manifests with diminished pedal pulses and cool skin, indicating impaired circulation. Dependent rubor, or reddening of the foot when lowered, occurs due to altered vasomotor responses and blood pooling. The delayed healing of cuts highlights compromised perfusion, as inadequate blood flow impairs the inflammatory and repair processes essential for tissue recovery.

Key learning point: In elderly diabetic patients, diminished pedal pulses, cold extremities, and redness that worsens in a dependent position are indicative of arterial insufficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy is associated with sensory changes like numbness or tingling, not vascular insufficiency. The cool foot, diminished pulses, and dependent redness indicate compromised blood flow, not nerve dysfunction. Poor wound healing with these vascular signs suggests arterial insufficiency.
